misconceptions.inferred_category_name: “Parallel arrays stay linked even after sorting one of them” (Reactive/linkage assumption)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` entries will somehow stay matched to their scores, so the last name in `names` will be the student who earned the highest (now-last) score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays don’t have any built-in relationship to each other. `Arrays.sort(scores)` only reorders the elements inside the `scores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder `names` to keep name–score pairs aligned. To maintain alignment, you must swap both arrays together during sorting, or store name+score together in an object and sort that collection.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the highest score, but often with the wrong student name (the name that happened to be last in input order).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: “Reading prompt text determines which variable gets the input” (Prompt-driven I/O model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student may believe that because they prompted for names first and scores second, the program will remember/associate those inputs as linked pairs (e.g., Alice’s name automatically pairs with Alice’s score), even though the code reads them in separate loops.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java input is purely positional/sequence-based: `scanner.next()` and `scanner.nextInt()` consume tokens in order and assign them to whatever variable you explicitly store them in. Prompts are just output text for the human; they do not create any binding between the earlier name tokens and later score tokens. If you want pairing, you must store paired data at the same index (e.g., read name and score per student in the same loop) and preserve that pairing during sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong mental model leading to design that breaks pairing during later operations (notably sorting). The immediate symptom appears as mismatched name/score after sorting.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Sorting Without Reordering References
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one array in a parallel array structure, the other array will automatically maintain its correspondence with the sorted array without explicit reordering. When `Arrays.sort(scores)` is called, the student thinks the indices will somehow stay aligned with the original names.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that `Arrays.sort()` only sorts the array it is called on in place. It does not modify or reorder other arrays. After sorting `scores`, the indices no longer correspond to the same student—the name at index `lastIndex` is no longer paired with the score at `lastIndex`. The parallel arrays have become misaligned. To maintain the correspondence, the student would need to either use a custom Comparator with a paired data structure (like an array of objects or two-array swap logic) or manually swap corresponding elements in both arrays during sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will print the correct highest score but will pair it with an incorrect name (whichever name was originally at the position where the highest score ended up after sorting).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the 'names' and 'scores' arrays were populated together as parallel data, any operation that reorders one array (like sorting) will automatically cause the other array to reorder itself to maintain the index-based relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The relationship between parallel arrays exists only in the logic of the programmer's access patterns. The Arrays.sort() method has no awareness of other arrays; it only reorders the elements of the specific array passed to it, breaking the index-based link between names and scores.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Synchronized-parallel-arrays misconception (sorting one array “reorders” the other)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will still line up by index (i.e., the student with the highest score will end up at the last index in both arrays).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` only permutes the `scores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate array (`names`) to keep pairs aligned. Parallel arrays require manually swapping elements in both arrays during sorting, or using a single array of objects/records (e.g., `Student{name, score}`) and sorting that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the highest score correctly (last element of sorted `scores`) but usually prints the wrong name (the name that happened to be last in the original input order).

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[lastIndex];
int topScore = scores[lastIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when Arrays.sort() is called on the scores array, the parallel names array automatically stays synchronized. They think that sorting is a 'global' operation that maintains the correspondence between related arrays without requiring explicit index tracking.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() operates ONLY on the specified array. Parallel arrays are completely independent in Java—sorting one array does NOT reorder elements in other arrays. When scores is sorted, the names array remains in its original order, breaking the correspondence between names[i] and scores[i].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. After sorting, the index of the highest score no longer corresponds to the correct student name. For the sample input (names: [Alice, Bob, Charlie], scores: [85, 92, 78]), sorting scores produces [78, 85, 92]. The code retrieves names[2]='Charlie' paired with scores[2]=92, but Bob had the score 92, not Charlie.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since the 'names' and 'scores' arrays are used to store related data at identical indices, the computer perceives them as a single bound entity (similar to a database table or Excel row) and will automatically reorder the 'names' array when the 'scores' array is sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java execution model, arrays are independent objects stored in discrete memory locations. The relationship between 'names[i]' and 'scores[i]' exists only in the programmer's logic, not in the machine state. A method like 'Arrays.sort()' only has a reference to the specific array passed to it and cannot implicitly synchronize with other arrays.
